bibl.title: Letter from John R. Bullard to Philip Showalter Hench, September 4, 1941

div1.p: Bullard describes his malaria attack. He clarifies his remarks about the Habana Yellow Fever Board.

div1.head: Letter from John R. Bullard to Philip Showalter Hench, September 4, 1941
div1.opener:
JRB
St. Augustine, Florida,
September 4, 1941.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Thanks for your let-
ter of the first and enclosure.

1. I was first smitten with malaria
at Artemisa where I was stopping with
a chap, now dead, who was starting
an orange grove; he had a superin-
tendent who was an old Florida crack-
er and who recognized at the second
attack of chills & fever that I had
malaria; my host knew Kean, got
in touch with him by telegraph
and I then went to Habana by
train (2 hrs. 10 min.) and thenceto Camp
Columbia and Kean's house in an
army waggon provided by Kean.

Our place at Dedham was closed
all that Summer of 1901 and my
mother, sister and brother were away.
I had been on the Cape and spent
part of a day and one might at Ded-
(over)
2
ham on business just prior to going
over to New York and embarking for
Cuba. It is, I think, true that there
was trench work going on in Dedham
at that time, but whether sewer,
water service or street railway, I do
not remember. It is also true
that two friends who were with
me on the Cape but who were
not at Dedham with me, came
down with malaria at about
the same time I did; this we
established several months later
by corresponding; both died - the
early 1930s.

2. Kean and Louise, his wife, both
of them, did all they could to dis-
suade me; Kean did not “rather
approve it” at all, but after I
came out all right, he thought
it was just fine and seemed to
be rather proud of me.

Corrections: Do just as you like
about the Habana Yellow Fever Board.
I originally told you “the Yellow Fever
Board from Habana”. That is all
I know about the Board except
that Dr. Finlay was on it and re-
cognized me. I thought that I
remembered that Agramonte came
too, but you suggested Albertini
whom I never knew, so I thought
I had made a mistake about
the proper name of the Board
which came to see us and
scratched out the Habana.

I regret all the trouble
I have caused you.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, John R. Bullard Dr. Philip S. Hench,
Rochester,
Minnesota.
